comments:
I20060921-0010

- in a text file editor, doubleclick the left ruler to add a bookmark
- in the Bookmarks view, select the Bookmark and press the Delete key

The issue here is that the BookmarkView has a key listener installed for the delete key, which runs the delete bookmark action.  Then the command handler for delete gets executed, which causes the delete action to run again.  Since the marker is deleted the first time, and the viewer is not yet updated, the second delete request tries to delete the same marker, which by this time no longer exists.

I can code around the NPE in AbstractMarkersOperation, but doing so will cause a different error dialog informing the user that the marker cannot be deleted because it no longer exists.  

The question is why there is a delete key handler in the view vs. relying on the command mechanism.  Having both is a problem.  This problem may have been around for awhile, with the second delete quietly failing, but now that the undo code is used, there is stricter error checking and information given the user, since undo commands can go stale.

Tod and/or Paul - any thoughts?  
I can code the remove bookmark action to check for non-existent markers and ignore them completely before creating the undo operation, but the right thing to do seems to be to avoid the duplication.
We should just use the command - the key listener is legacy code.

okay...the relevant code is in MarkerView, so this will effect BookmarkView, ProblemView, and TaskView.
 
I will release the fix for M3.  This is not a showstopper for M2 because the delete bookmark does in fact complete, and the undo/redo stack remains stable (ie, you can still undo and redo the delete).

Fixed >20060922.

- removed delete key handling in MarkerView
- changed AbstractMarkersOperation to handle the NPE since there may be other odd cases where the marker won't exist during the execution of the constructor.  Instead, the user would get an error when the operation actually ran, informing them that the marker does not exist.
